channel.title: Guitar
channel.description:
Since I cant come up with original ideas..
I copyed STH :\
The basic model of the things are done.
[IMG]http://img356.imageshack.us/img356/7877/guitarnf6.jpg[/img]

item.title: Guitar
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Add a point.
In the first part, I’d add one where the part of the tri is facing the outside. Then move those points around so it fits better.

have a look at my guitar wireframe. It’s kinda messy because it’s made to be hypernurbed, but there’s no triangles.

nevermind. I made the hypernurbs editable, so you can’t see the original, but have a look at the headstock.

I made the outline, then connected the points so they’re all quads.

Read full topic

item.title: Guitar
item.dc:creator: @FastBallz FastBawlz
item.description:
@FastBallz wrote:

Ahh I see…

Trying to see how I would go about making a tri into a quad

Read full topic

item.title: Guitar
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Yeah. That’s an n-gon. You want lots of quads, not one giant polygon with > 4 sides.

It’s kinda hard to tell you exactly what to do. Get the knife tool, and make sure it’s on the Line option.

Cut from each point to another so you have all four sided polygons.

If that doesn’t work out easily, there’s something else you can do.

Start over. And instead of making one big polygon, make quads.

Start at the top left, and make a quad that fits a small part. Then make another quad, with two of it’s vertices connected to the last, kinda like you’re making a row. Do that over and over fitting the shape of the guitar.

Read full topic

item.title: Guitar
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Yeah. He just did a slightly modified way of doing it.

I never ever model with edges.

The easiest and cleanest way to do my guitar was to make a giant polygon shaped like it.

Then you have to visualize everything and find where to cut it so you have no triangles, alone polys, or non-planar polys.

Read full topic

Just google poly modeling tutorials.

This one kinda shows you. See how the modeling looks nice?
http://www.highend3d.com/maya/tutorials/modeling/polygon/303.html[/quote]Lol damn, is that how you do it? I wasn’t even close.

item.title: Guitar
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Okay Fast. That’s good.
Now, make sure it’s not an n-gon, as it probably is.

It can’t have more than 4 sides per polygon. So get out the knife tool and make sure you’re in point mode so you can hook on to the points you’ve already made. Make it very even, remember, four sides to each one.

Then when you’re done, select them all, and Extrude (make sure Create Caps is on too).

Read full topic

item.title: Guitar
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

lmao.

You just want things neat. Basically.
A very simple way of checking too, is HyperNURBS.

Apply one to your object. If you get lots of ugly bump, ridges, or ugly artifacts, you did bad.
But if you get a smooth object, that you can work with, it should be fine.

Read full topic

item.title: Guitar
item.dc:creator: @FastBallz FastBawlz
item.description:
@FastBallz wrote:

[quote=“SomethingToHide, post:6, topic:139831”]Painting = Pink Floyd Album. Scenery I guess, for the mood.

TV = Amp lmfao. Can’t tell the brand cause the signiture at the top is kinda unseeable (word?).[/quote]

Amp Sig. = Bawlz

Painting = Ya mood…

[quote=“SomethingToHide, post:4, topic:139831”]Nah. You could beat me.

Though the way you made it might make it tons more difficult.

I can try not to give a humongous lecture on polygon theory.
But you want a very clean model.
No triangles, just quads.

That’s why I didn’t use a spline.
Create the outline of the shape with the polygon tool. Then get the knife and connect the points and add a few more to make the model “perfect”
That’s what’s hard to teach. You want something that you can easily work with, and that will look great under a hypernurbs.

I guess an easy way to say it is, make it look like a checkerboard. You don’t want polygons flying everywhere, you want them all evened out. If that makes sense. I’ll show you my wireframe later.[/quote]

I kinda see what your saying, but at the same time I have no fucking idea… So i used the polygon tool to make a polygon…

And as you can see, its not choppy… but its not thick either :\

Read full topic

item.title: Guitar
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Nah. You could beat me.

Though the way you made it might make it tons more difficult.

I can try not to give a humongous lecture on polygon theory.
But you want a very clean model.
No triangles, just quads.

That’s why I didn’t use a spline.
Create the outline of the shape with the polygon tool. Then get the knife and connect the points and add a few more to make the model “perfect”
That’s what’s hard to teach. You want something that you can easily work with, and that will look great under a hypernurbs.

I guess an easy way to say it is, make it look like a checkerboard. You don’t want polygons flying everywhere, you want them all evened out. If that makes sense. I’ll show you my wireframe later.

Read full topic
